Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing an Intergovernmental Management Framework for Sustainable Recovery Following Catastrophic Disasters

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will use the 2008 Wenchuan earthquake - which affected 46 million people in western China, caused over 88,000 deaths, and paralyzed the economy of a large part of Sichuan province - to answer the following question: What can government do to ensure that post-disaster recovery is fast, fair, efficient, and sustainable? Managing reconstruction following catastrophic disasters is especially challenging, because of the pressure to rebuild everything in a short time. An effective recovery process can help minimize the long-term effects of a disaster on a community. To accomplish its goal, this project will study the recovery planning and management strategies used at national, provincial, and local levels following the Wenchuan earthquake. It will also survey households to find out about the actual results of the Chinese recovery policies. A bilingual team of researchers will meet with officials and collect recovery documents from all three levels of government, and the household survey will be conducted by Chinese university students.

This research will greatly improve our understanding of recovery management after catastrophic disasters. In order to gain a deep understanding of post-disaster recovery, it is necessary to study events in a variety of settings. A detailed study of the Chinese style of recovery management, in the current era of rapid change in China, will help to broaden our understanding of post-catastrophe recovery management processes. In addition, the Chinese strategy includes some unique aspects that may be worth emulating or adapting to U.S. situations. An important aspect of this project is the research exchange and mutual learning about post-disaster recovery in China and the U.S. Researchers will work closely with Chinese colleagues in designing and executing the field research in China. The Chinese colleagues will have the opportunity to travel to the U.S. to learn about post-disaster recovery policies. The team's previous experiences in studying disaster recovery in other places indicate that this exchange will lead to continued collaboration that will advance the practice of recovery management in both countries. Furthermore, because members of the research team are involved in U.S. recovery practice and policy, the results of the research will influence future U.S. approaches to disaster recovery planning and management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied the rapid reconstruction process following the 2008 Wenchuan Earthquake, a devastating earthquake that damaged over five million housing units over a wide area of Sichuan Province, China, and required investments of $147 billion for reconstruction. Our purpose in studying this event was to learn about managing post-disaster recovery after very large disasters. The management process after this earthquake was notable, because so many different governments were involved, including the central government, many provinces, and a large number of local governments.  For this reason, this case provided an opportunity to study the coordination of many governmental organizations in achieving a remarkably fast reconstruction after a large-scale disaster.

Our overall research question was: What are appropriate governmental roles and actions in order to ensure that recovery is fast, equitable, efficient, and sustainable?  Our research covered three general topics: reconstruction policies by various levels of government, relocation and financing policies that were unique to this case, and the outcomes of these policies. Over the course of three years, we interviewed dozens of officials at all levels of government, gathered numerous university and governmental books and reports, conducted field observations, and surveyed 322 households in the most damaged areas.

At a national scale, one important set of lessons involved the “pair-assistance” system, by which the central government assigned wealthy eastern provinces to assist each of the most heavily damaged counties in the western part of China. This system was very effective, both as a way of financing construction and also as a way of mobilizing large numbers of planners, designers, and builders from the donor provinces to rapidly reconstruct the damaged cities.  Another important factor affecting the speed and coordination of the reconstruction was that the central government made reconstruction a top priority for the nation as a whole. Because of this, they were able to encourage funding from a variety of sources, in addition to the pair-assistance program: financial institution loans, government budgetary savings, capital markets, private donations, and foreign loans. In many places, local governments traded the value of land to pay for reconstruction. Through the media, the central government also mobilized the entire country to contribute generously with donations.

Although the physical reconstruction was rapid—most of it was completed within two years of the earthquake—most of it lacked consultation with affected people. As a result, the land use designs and locations were not always ideal.  Most, but not all, reconstruction projects lacked substantial public involvement. Furthermore, the reconstruction emphasized production of housing, with much less thought given to livelihoods.  As a result of the haste, lack of involvement, and emphasis on housing, we found evidence that the economic recovery was not nearly as successful as the physical recovery.  For one, many farmers were relocated to clusters of urbanized housing that made it more difficult for them to tend their fields. Second, the most visible economic development strategies appeared to be based more on optimism than on analysis: new industrial parks with few tenants, and an unrealistic expectation that tourism will be able to drive the economies of all the mountain towns.

Despite the high visibility of the pair assistance program, our research also found that the reconstruction depended on large amounts of private and public/private financing, amounts far exceeding that of the pair assistance.
